diagrams.description: Foreign Trade history spans from ancient commerce routes to modern digital trade systems. The Silk Road (200 BCE-1400s CE) connected East and West through overland trade. Mercantilism dominated 16th-18th centuries, emphasizing exports over imports and colonial extraction. The Corn Laws repeal (1846) in Britain marked a shift toward free trade principles. The Smoot-Hawley Tariff Act (1930) raised US duties, worsening the Great Depression and demonstrating protectionism's dangers. The General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (1947) initiated multilateral trade liberalization. Containerization (1956) revolutionized shipping efficiency and global trade volumes. The Uruguay Round (1994) created the WTO and expanded trade rules to services and intellectual property. China's WTO accession (2001) reshaped global trade patterns. Today's foreign trade integrates digital platforms, blockchain documentation, and sustainability-linked trade policies.

timeline
    title Foreign Trade Evolution
    200 BCE-1400s : Silk Road Era
                  : East-West trade routes
    1600s-1700s : Mercantilism

    1846 : Corn Laws Repeal
         : Free trade shift in Britain
    1930 : Smoot-Hawley Tariff
         : Protectionism consequences
    1947 : GATT Established
         : Multilateral liberalization
    1956 : Containerization
         : Shipping revolution
    1994 : WTO Creation
         : Uruguay Round expansion
    2001 : China Joins WTO
         : Global trade transformation
    2020s : Digital Trade Era
          : Blockchain & sustainability
